metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: The <path> element is used to define a path.
content.html: The <path> element is used to define a path.

content.text: Paths are used to create simple or complex shapes combining several straight or curved lines.
content.html: Paths are used to create simple or complex shapes combining several straight or curved lines.

content.text: The <path> element has one basic attribute that defines the points and other commands of how to draw the path:
content.html: The <path> element has one basic attribute that defines the points and other commands of how to draw the path:

content.code_html:
Attribute Description
d Required. A set of commands which define the path.

The following commands are available for path data:

  • M = moveto (move from one point to another point)
  • L = lineto (create a line)
  • H = horizontal lineto (create a horizontal line)
  • V = vertical lineto (create a vertical line)
  • C = curveto (create a curve)
  • S = smooth curveto (create a smooth curve)
  • Q = quadratic Bézier curve (create a quadratic Bézier curve)
  • T = smooth quadratic Bézier curveto (create a smooth quadratic Bézier curve)
  • A = elliptical Arc (create a elliptical arc)
  • Z = closepath (close the path)

Note: All of the commands above can also be expressed in lower case. Upper case means absolutely positioned, lower case means relatively positioned.

content.text: The example below defines a path that starts at position 150,5 with a line to position 75,200 then from there, a line to 225,200 and finally closing the path back to 150,5:
content.html: The example below defines a path that starts at position 150,5 with a line to position 75,200 then from there, a line to 225,200 and finally closing the path back to 150,5:

content.code:
<svg height="210" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

<path d="M150 5 L75 200 L225 200 Z"  
style="fill:none;stroke:green;stroke-width:3" />

</svg>
content.code_html:
<svg height="210" width="400" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <path d="M150 5 L75 200 L225 200 Z"
  style="fill:none;stroke:green;stroke-width:3" />
</svg>

content.text: Bézier curves are used to model smooth curves that can be scaled indefinitely. Generally, the user selects two endpoints and one or two control points. A Bézier curve with one control point is called a quadratic Bézier curve.
content.html: Bézier curves are used to model smooth curves that can be scaled indefinitely. Generally, the user selects two endpoints and one or two control points. A Bézier curve with one control point is called a quadratic Bézier curve.

content.text: The following example creates a quadratic Bézier curve, where A and C are the start and end points, B is the control point:
content.html: The following example creates a quadratic Bézier curve, where A and C are the start and end points, B is the control point:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<path id="lineAC" d="M 100 350 q 150 -300 
  300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/>

id="lineAC" d="M 100 350 q 150 -300 
  300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/

content.code:
<svg height="400" width="450" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">


<!-- Draw the paths -->
<path id="lineAB" d="M 100 350 l 150 -300" 
stroke="red" stroke-width="4"/>
<path id="lineBC" d="M 250 50 l 150 300" 
stroke="red" stroke-width="4"/>
<path id="lineMID" d="M 175 200 l 150 0" 
stroke="green" stroke-width="4"/>
<path id="lineAC" d="M 100 350 q 150 -300 
300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/>

<!-- Mark relevant 
points -->
<g stroke="black" stroke-width="3" fill="black">
<circle id="pointA" 
cx="100" cy="350" r="4" />
<circle id="pointB" cx="250" cy="50" r="4" />

<circle id="pointC" cx="400" cy="350" r="4" />
</g>

<!-- Label the 
points -->
<g font-size="30" font-family="sans-serif" fill="green" 
text-anchor="middle">
<text x="100" y="350" dx="-30">A</text>
<text 
x="250" y="50" dy="-10">B</text>
<text x="400" y="350" dx="30">C</text>

</g>

</svg>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<path id="lineAC" d="M 100 350 q 150 -300 
  300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/>

id="lineAC" d="M 100 350 q 150 -300 
  300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/

content.code_html:
<svg height="400" width="450" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

<!-- Draw the paths -->
<path id="lineAB" d="M 100 350 l 150 -300" stroke="red" stroke-width="4"/>
<path id="lineBC" d="M 250 50 l 150 300" stroke="red" stroke-width="4"/>
<path id="lineMID" d="M 175 200 l 150 0" stroke="green" stroke-width="4"/>
<path id="lineAC" d="M 100 350 q 150 -300 300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/>

<!-- Mark relevant points -->
<g stroke="black" stroke-width="3" fill="black">
<circle id="pointA" cx="100" cy="350" r="4" />
<circle id="pointB" cx="250" cy="50" r="4" />
<circle id="pointC" cx="400" cy="350" r="4" />
</g>

<!-- Label the points -->
<g font-size="30" font-family="sans-serif" fill="green" text-anchor="middle">
<text x="100" y="350" dx="-30">A</text>
<text x="250" y="50" dy="-10">B</text>
<text x="400" y="350" dx="30">C</text>
</g>

</svg>

<path id="lineAC" d="M 100 350 q 150 -300 
  300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/>

id="lineAC" d="M 100 350 q 150 -300 
  300 0" stroke="blue" stroke-width="4" fill="none"/

content.text: Complex? YES!!!! Because of the complexity involved in drawing paths it is highly recommended to use an SVG editor to create complex graphics.
content.html: Complex? YES!!!! Because of the complexity involved in drawing paths it is highly recommended to use an SVG editor to create complex graphics.
